title.value: Heterogeneous Crowd Simulation Using Parametric Reinforcement Learning
title.justification: This is clearly stated as the title in the given text.
title.quote: Heterogeneous Crowd Simulation Using Parametric Reinforcement Learning

extractions.description: This paper presents a model-free, reinforcement learning-based approach for simulating heterogeneous crowds with predictive reciprocal collision avoidance and parametric policy learning.

type.justification: The study involves extensive evaluation and validation of the proposed model through various qualitative and quantitative experiments.
type.quote: The model is extensively evaluated. The results show policy generalization across unseen scenarios, agent parameters, and out-of-distribution parameterizations.

name.justification: The core methodology employed in the paper for policy learning is reinforcement learning.
name.quote: In this paper, we present a multi-agent reinforcement learning-based approach that learns a parametric predictive collision avoidance and steering policy.

name.justification: The primary application domain of the research is to simulate synthetic crowds.
name.quote: Agent-based synthetic crowd simulation affords the cost-effective large-scale simulation and animation of interacting digital humans.

name.justification: The paper focuses on multi-agent reinforcement learning and behavior of multiple agents in a shared environment.
name.quote: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning (MARL) extends this by having multiple agents within the same shared environment where their actions may impact each other.

name.value: Heterogeneous crowds using Parametric Reinforcement Learning (HOP-RL)
name.justification: The model introduced in the paper is Heterogeneous crowds using Parametric Reinforcement Learning (HOP-RL).
name.quote: We propose the Heterogeneous crowds using Parametric Reinforcement Learning (HOP-RL) approach to steering in synthetic crowd simulation.

is_contributed.justification: The model HOP-RL is introduced as a new contribution in this paper.
is_contributed.quote: We propose the Heterogeneous crowds using Parametric Reinforcement Learning (HOP-RL) approach to steering in synthetic crowd simulation.

is_executed.justification: The model was implemented and extensively evaluated in various simulations and scenarios.
is_executed.quote: The model is extensively evaluated. The results show policy generalization across unseen scenarios, agent parameters, and out-of-distribution parameterizations.

is_compared.justification: The model was compared against other methods such as Reciprocal Velocity Obstacles (RVO) and Predictive Avoidance Model (PAM) in several experiments.
is_compared.quote: We evaluate the quantitative quality of our learned steering policy by comparing HOP-RL with both the industry baselines and two baseline RL-based approaches over the steering models metrics introduced in Section 4.1.

referenced_paper_title.justification: Since HOP-RL is a primary contribution of this paper, there is no referenced paper title for it.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We propose the Heterogeneous crowds using Parametric Reinforcement Learning (HOP-RL) approach to steering in synthetic crowd simulation.

name.justification: The Reciprocal Velocity Obstacles (RVO) model is used for comparison in the experiments.
name.quote: We evaluate the quantitative quality of our learned steering policy by comparing HOP-RL with both the industry baselines and two baseline RL-based approaches over the steering models metrics introduced in Section 4.1.

is_contributed.justification: This model is used as a baseline for comparison and not introduced by the paper.
is_contributed.quote: We evaluate the quantitative quality of our learned steering policy by comparing HOP-RL with both the industry baselines and two baseline RL-based approaches over the steering models metrics introduced in Section 4.1.

is_executed.justification: The focus of the paper is on the HOP-RL model, not on the implementation of RVO.
is_executed.quote: This model is a highly optimized internal (black box) implementation shipped with the Unity game engine.

is_compared.justification: RVO is one of the models against which HOP-RL is compared.
is_compared.quote: We evaluate the quantitative quality of our learned steering policy by comparing HOP-RL with both the industry baselines and two baseline RL-based approaches over the steering models metrics introduced in Section 4.1.

referenced_paper_title.value: Reciprocal Velocity Obstacles for real-time multi-agent navigation
referenced_paper_title.justification: Referenced as the source of the RVO model, which is used for comparison.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Van den Berg, J., Lin, M., & Manocha, D. (2008). Reciprocal velocity obstacles for real-time multi-agent navigation. In 2008 IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Automation (pp. 1928-1935). IEEE.

name.justification: The Predictive Avoidance Model (PAM) is also used for comparison in the experiments.
name.quote: We evaluate the quantitative quality of our learned steering policy by comparing HOP-RL with both the industry baselines and two baseline RL-based approaches over the steering models metrics introduced in Section 4.1.

is_contributed.justification: This model is used as a baseline for comparison and not introduced by the paper.
is_contributed.quote: We evaluate the quantitative quality of our learned steering policy by comparing HOP-RL with both the industry baselines and two baseline RL-based approaches over the steering models metrics introduced in Section 4.1.

is_executed.justification: The focus of the paper is on the HOP-RL model, not on the implementation of PAM.
is_executed.quote: Predictive Avoidance Model (PAM) â€“ a physics-based approach that predicts linear collisions and applies appropriate avoidance forces.

is_compared.justification: PAM is one of the models against which HOP-RL is compared.
is_compared.quote: We evaluate the quantitative quality of our learned steering policy by comparing HOP-RL with both the industry baselines and two baseline RL-based approaches over the steering models metrics introduced in Section 4.1.

referenced_paper_title.value: A Predictive Collision Avoidance Model for Pedestrian Simulation
referenced_paper_title.justification: Referenced as the source of the PAM model, which is used for comparison.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Karamouzas, I., Heil, P., van Beek, P., & Overmars, M. H. (2009). A predictive collision avoidance model for pedestrian simulation. In International Workshop on Motion in Games (pp. 41-52). Springer, Berlin, Heidelberg.

name.justification: Unity game engine was used for implementing experimental scenarios and performance evaluations.
name.quote: This model is a highly optimized internal (black box) implementation shipped with the Unity game engine.

referenced_paper_title.justification: There is no specific reference paper title for Unity as it is a well-known game engine.
referenced_paper_title.quote: This model is a highly optimized internal (black box) implementation shipped with the Unity game engine.
